title: The Crossing of the Granicus, from The Story of Alexander the Great

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave.

artist_display:
After a design by, and woven at the workshop of, Karel van Mander the Younger (1579–1623)
Holland, Delft
description: This tapestry dramatizes a battle fought in 334 B.C. between the Macedonians and the Persians. Alexander the great, king of the Macedonians, is depicted just left of center; dressed in ornate gilt armor, he rides a white horse and raises a sword boldly above his head. Facing him is a Persian general on a dark horse with both hands grasped around an axe. Although Alexander appears imperiled, he was ultimately victorious in the battle. the tense moment represented here provided a compelling narrative for noble patrons in the 17th century, willing to imagine Alexander's triumphs as equivalent to their own.
medium_display: Wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave
credit_line: Gift of the Antiquarian Society of the Art Institute of Chicago
publication_history:
"Flemish Tapestry, "Bulletin of The Art Institute of Chicago", vol. 6, no. 2 Oct 1912, p. 21 reproduced

Hunter 1914, p. 120, no. 5. 

Hunter, G. L., "The Practical Book of Tapestries," Philadelphia, 1925, p. 136.

The Antiquarian Society of the Art Institute of Chicago, "The First One Hundred Years," Chicago: A.I.C., 1977, No. 242, ill. p. 185

Hartkamp-Jonix and Smit 2004, p. 224, fig. 84.

Koenraad Brosens, ed., Christa C. Mayer Thurman, gen. ed., European Tapestries in the Art Institute of Chicago, exh. cat., [exhibition: "The Divine Art: Four Centuries of European Tapestries in the Art Institute of Chicago"] (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2008) 341-344, cat. 57.
exhibition_history:
The Art Institute of Chicago, The Antiquarian Society of The Art Institute of Chicago: The First One Hundred Years, April 23– 19, 1977

The Art Institute of Chicago, Regenstein Hall, The Divine Art: Four Centuries of European Tapestry, November 1, 2008–January 4, 2009

The Art Institute of Chicago, The Deering Family Galleries, Gallery 239A, March 17, 2017-March 28, 2018
provenance_text: Prince Anatoli Demidoff (died 1870), Villa San Donato, Florence, Italy, presumably from 1840; by descent to his nephew Paul Demidoff (1839-1885); sold at auction from Villa San Donato, Florence, 1880, lot 109 (all nine tapestries). Jennie McGraw Fiske (d. 1881), Ithaca, New York, to 1881; presumably by decent to her husband Daniel Willard Fiske (d. 1904) or another relative. Purchased by the Antiquarian Society of the Art Institute of Chicago for $10,000, 1911; given to the Art Institute, 1911.

input: The Crossing of the Granicus, from The Story of Alexander the Great
